pros:
UMass Amherst employment means that you'll be working in a large organization with a lot of moving parts. There's unions operating for many parts of the system (though notably, not undergraduate students). Generally the managers are pretty fair across departments.

UMass will also try to address harassment claims in general? They're at least more attentive to it than some employers, although they aren't always efficient with their HR.
cons: UMass has quite a bad bureaucracy, with constantly rotating people in all positions. There are certainly good people within this bureaucracy, and they normally keep it together, but not always. One has to roll with the punches so to speak, especially if they want to go deeper into UMass employment. This is true from service positions to more specific administrative ones.

review_title: Graduate student union real makes a difference
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Amherst, MA
pros: UMass Amherst graduate student employees are unionized (the GEO, part of the UAW union) and the union negotiates regular pay increases and great health insurance benefits as well as other benefits. Relative to other campus in the U.S., UMass Amherst pays its graduate students quite well. This works out particularly well given that the cost of living is not as absurd as in big cities (e.g., Boston, or New Haven).
cons: As a graduate student, you still get underpaid for the value you bring, but that's not an issue that is specific to UMass Amherst. Also, graduate students not employed by the University (including those with a break in employment say for a semester) loose the union (GEO) benefits until they are rehired.

review_title: UMass Chemistry Ph.D. program is excellent, highly recommended
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Amherst, MA
pros: The chemistry department has a high level of expertise throughout every chemistry subdiscipline - something for everyone: analytical, inorganic, organic, biochemistry, spectroscopy, physical, and materials. There is a huge amount of research funding, and an extensive collaboration and employment network. Studying graduate level chemistry at UMass has opened a lot of doors for me, and has been an overall enjoyable experience.
cons: The stipend is not as large as I think it should be, and there are too many "administrative" fees. We are treated like students when the university wants fees, and we are treated like staff when it comes time to pay for going to the gym (which undergrads get for free).

review_title: If you can deal with sacrificing free time, it's a good job
job_title: IT Help Consultant in Amherst, MA
pros:
(I was hired at the IT User Services department, so the following applies to this department only)
-Flexible hours
-Understanding management
-No prerequisites, fairly easy work once trained
-Teaches very useful skills that can help later on life
cons:
-Depending on your school schedule and willingness to work, can take up a lot of free time and add stress
-Depending on which of the two locations you get scheduled to work at you will be able to do limited homework during downtime
-Depending on where you live, commuting, whether it be an actual commute by car or bus, or just walking from your dormitory, to work can potentially be a bit long

job_title: Dinning Commons Employee in Amherst, MA
pros: Much support provided to students working in summer programs. The location is at a familiar place and the responsibilities are clearly laid out. There is always a possibility to continue after the term has ended, and the flexibility allows students to focus on their studies while working to support themselves.
cons: The competitive and rewarding jobs only last a short term throughout the year. Year-long jobs are plenty but with the massive workforce available the pay rate is usually the state minimum.

pros:
-Super flexible schedule.
-Accommodating supervisors.
-Opportunities for growth/raises.
-Generally pleasant co-workers.

For a student job it is really hard to go wrong. They work with your class schedule and you can end up working a lot of overtime if you want to. Had very few complaints with my time there.
cons:
-It can be a cliquey place, if you don't fit in with the transit "culture" it can be more difficult to get rid of shifts, etc.

review_title: Long and boring work, yet connective and humbling.
job_title: Food Service Assistant in Amherst, MA
pros:
- It's a cool experience to be involved in parts of the cooking process.
- It can be a very social experience between talking to the students you're serving as they wait in line and of course to your coworkers.
- Most (but not all) of the supervisors are quite amicable and fair.
cons:
- Hours can be long, especially as you stand in one place for more than three hours.
- One can easily be influenced by the moods of those you're consistently serving, making you become less sociable.
- It can be difficult to get days off because you must find someone to replace you.

job_title: Aux Crew Member in Amherst, MA
pros: Students are nice to work with and the environment is very laid back. You will find that it can be a great place to work if you aren't too itchy to get your work done at the gestest place possible.
cons: Leadership can be lax sometimes.  You may find one day you appreciate that the boss isn't getting down your throat but the next day when your trying to do your best and others decided to be a bit lazy it can be rather frustrating.

review_title: Graduate Stipend Helps with the Bills
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Amherst, MA
pros: Helps build valuable experience that can be leveraged when pursuing future employment. Some supervisors are great and you will gain great experience, but your mileage may vary.
cons: Hard to find new positions within the University. New opportunities is all about who you know because many positions are not posted until they are filled, even though they are required to announce all positions as part of our contracts. Chancellor was quoted as saying that graduate students signed up for life of poverty by becoming graduate students.

pros: People are generally friendly and if you're fortunate enough to work in a department with money, the buildings and office spaces are quite nice.
cons: Training is severely lacking; different people from the same department give you separate responses to questions which can cause big problems.  Almost no merit system if you're classified staff; you are instead rewarded by how long you stay with the company rather than the hard work you do.  Extremely limited career growth unless you switch departments; promotions don't exist for classified staff.

pros: These were wonderfully flexible people and most of the management were quite friendly and helpful. Many of the employees were genial as well! Good amount of independence and individuality allowed in our writing and posting too.
cons: A couple of the students employed there could be snooty. Also, UMass has a tendency to hire mostly work-study kids, which means that it's cheaper labor for the university, rather than paying their workers a typical wage. Kind of common in modern U.S. colleges, though.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Amherst, MA
pros: The research/professor selection is great, and fantastic instrumentation.  Also a prime spot for industrial recruiters of Ph.D. students.  A good place to be a grad student, though obviously your actual life will be affected greatly by the professor you work for.  That new 500 NMR though.  The best.
cons: Naturally grad student hours are pretty grueling, and the compensation isn't great.  Also, it's called Zoo-Mass for a reason, and that can be a good or a bad thing depending on what you're looking for (more in terms of undergrads).

review_title: Work study students get low pay and even summer full-time payment sucks
pros: Good research experience, terrible pay. If you start off as work study, depending on the funding your lab gets, you can exhaust your work study funds (where they 1/4 for each dollar) and you ca n be placed on the lab's funding.
cons: Low pay, you really have to find another job or a sugar daddy to pay for rent if you live off campus..

pros: Perfect summer job for any student staying in the area during the summer. Low stress 40 hours a week, and was out by 3pm to enjoy my summer days.
cons: Sometimes there wasn't enough to do to keep busy, but if you got caught taking any breaks you could get in trouble.

pros: The education that one is able to receive is outstanding, the people are generally very helpful, and my supervisor wanted me to succeed.  It is expansive enough to be able to have many different challenges in the one day that it would be very hard to ever find it boring to work there.  I loved UMass Amherst, the Flagship campus!  Anyone would love it too.
cons: I did not find any cons when I was there.  If they were there, I was fortunate to have experienced them.

review_title: The Off Campus Student Center is a great place to work!
job_title: Off Campus Assistant in Amherst, MA
pros: Working as an off campus assistant is great. The supervisors (two grad students and a Dean) are friendly, communicative and encouraging. Coworkers are always willing to trade shifts, there are very flexible hours and UMass is required to place your course schedule as priority, so there are no conflicts with classes!
cons: Most student jobs make minimum wage, scheduling can be hectic.

review_title: the best job i have had
pros: the supervisor is a great mentor, and friend.  This job is just like another college course, where you get to learn not only about the job itself, but about yourself, and the different things about the world.  I had great time working there.
cons: it last too short,  it is a work study job, i had to quit after i leave the school.  sometimes, the job can get extremely boring and tedious that will put you to sleep.

review_title: A great short term place to work!
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Amherst, MA
pros: It's great to work with engaged people who care about what they're doing and are hopeful for their futures. I mostly worked with PhD candidates and they were interesting and smart and kind. Work-life balance is easy, as nearly everyone is also working on dissertations and dealing with young families.
cons: Co-workers can get overwhelmed by other responsibilities and disappear to finish a dissertation, for example. but when it's your turn to finish a huge project, you'll be glad for the luxury.

pros: I have enjoyed the flexible work schedule and ability to work from home. The research I do is interesting, and it's nice to have some ability to direct my own work and research.
cons: The hiring process is a real bureaucratic slog, it took me over two months of work before I got my first paycheck.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Amherst, MA
pros: Provides you everything you need to develop your self, courses, degrees, and teaching assistant positions. Free courses and degrees for employees, helps a lot. Also Amherst is a great town to enjoy.
cons: Salary is not remarkably high. But still this university is an opportunity provider, so salary would not be the point of working here for, and living cost in Amherst is not high.

pros: UMass Amherst administration tend to be more forward thinking, and there is a genuine commitment towards the students. Most administrators work regularly with students to help address problems on campus.
cons: It is a very bureaucratic work environment; administration is very slow-paced and projects do not move fast on this campus in any department.

pros: Great team, easy access to collaborators due to sheer number of departments. Labs are well equipped. Travel funds are not really a problem.
cons: The HR department is a bit inefficient, takes long to process even simple requests.  Libraries are not well equipped to support research and getting books through interlibrary loan just slows thing down.

review_title: Really Great for a Student Trying to get into Research
pros: I was in the physics department.  They basically funded my research as if I were doing the work of a grad student.  I had incredible opportunities and I never had to pull teeth to get them.  The experience I had working for UMass was valuable and unique.
cons: The fact that it's such a big school inevitably means you're a number most of the time.

review_title: Best college job you could have.
pros:
Good pay for a college students. 
-They pay you while you are training to get your CDL and cover your road test. 
-The people who work there are extremely friendly. 
-Hours are extremely flexible to meet your academic needs.
cons: Sometimes you have to deal with large numbers of drunk college students and crazy locals, however sometimes they can be fun and entertaining. So it depends on how you deal with those situations.

job_title: Customer Service Associate in Amherst, MA
pros: There are plenty of opportunities to move up on the employment ladder. The salary for a college student does not leave much to be desired.
cons: The communication between offices is unsatisfactory, so there is a lot of assuming involved in the job. Managers sometimes expect you to know what you are doing even if the instructions are unclear.

pros: I have been living here for more than five years, the climate here is great except that the winter is too long. The food in the dinning common is awesome
cons: I think this is common problem for many universities in small towns. the location is not good enough for job hunting, compare with those in big cities

review_title: Depends on where you are working, lots of different types of opportunities.
pros: Lots of different types of job opportunities, lots of opportunity for laboratory work which usually pays the best. You could also work as a TA possibly or work as a office assistant, some potential to learn helpful stuff.
cons: Otherwise you will likely get minimum wage. Lots of useless jobs that no one else wants to do, especially dining services.

pros: There is a graduate student union which advocates for the rights of the working graduate students. This includes negotiating for benefits and pay raises. 95% of the health insurance plan is paid for by the university for working graduate students. It is amazing.
cons: Depending on what department you are in it can be difficult to find student assistantships (paid positions)

review_title: Choose the lab you enter wisely
pros: The techniques that each lab runs are usually developed to be robust and set up to teach newcomers the basics.
cons: Developments happen slowly; you will be pushed into projects that you don't necessarily want to do, whether it will further your career or not.

review_title: Great place to work as a teaching assistant or research assistant.
pros: The faculty that I worked with at UMass were all top-notch. The professors at UMass are mostly considerate people who genuinely appreciate their teaching assistants and are flexible with scheduling because they understand that students are also busy with coursework.
cons: The pay was about the same as another other campus job. Professors discouraged teaching assistants from having another job the side.

pros: Amherst is a great place to live, nice surroundings, and people in town are friendly. During the summer, you can enjoy local groceries. For graduate employee, you can have high faculty-student ratio, which means you may get more attention from faculty members.
cons: The biggest problem is the benefits and hourly rate as well as working hours may not be very good and secure for graduate employee

review_title: Good place to work while getting a graduate degree.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Amherst, MA
pros: Great health benefits. Pays for tuition and gives you stipend. Flexible hours.
cons: Always overcharge you each semester for various bills. However, a call or email can fix this. Stipend could be increased since the cost of living is fairly high in the area due to the demand for rental properties.

review_title: Good University to work for, but could be great!
job_title: Business Systems Analyst in Amherst, MA
pros: The people are great and so are the benefits!  The university is working to move forward and upward towards greater heights.
cons: Pay Rates are below market, lots of un-benefited employees are hired in certain departments where benefits should be given.  The salary classification system is old and broken and doesn't work for today's jobs and market.

review_title: Graduate student in the Geosciences Department
pros: The department has a very collegial atmosphere. Most professors and graduate students are more than happy to talk with undergraduates and each other. Research equipment and lab space is shared. Overall, this is a very supportive environment for grad students. Also, we have a union and teaching assistants get health and dental insurance at an affordable price.
cons: Funding can be an issue, depending on the professor. Also, the office space tends to be crowded.

job_title: Service Desk Clerk in Amherst, MA
pros: The hours are very flexible and the workload is minimal. Much of the time is spent sitting at the desk answering any questions which means you can get a lot of school work done.
cons: The supervisors can be very particular and strict about small details and will often hold mistakes against you.

review_title: It depends heavily on your department and supervisors
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Amherst, MA
pros:
A great way to understand the teaching-learning process
Collaborative and supportive work environment
Some really great Professors, who make this experience a highlight of your grad years
cons: The review system can be unfair if you try to make students learn something seriously and sincerely, instead of just giving them whatever grades they want

pros: The university has a rich, intellectual environment so you get to work with really smart, passionate people.  Working with students is inspiring, too.
cons: If you're not faculty, career management, as it should anyway, becomes a personal responsibility and sometimes a person may find themselves working for someone with little or no management experience or training.

review_title: A good experience but employees are not valued as greatly as upper management.
job_title: Customer Service Associate in Amherst, MA
pros: Good Food, Good housing and a safe and positive environment.
cons: Employees easily replaceable so not valued highly. Be sure to not get in any conflicts with any upper management because I have never seen that work out in the employees favor.

review_title: Loved both attending this great university and working for it, wish I decided to become an RA after my freshman year
pros: Free room, severely reduced parking in lot 11 and a nice salary stipend, as a current student this helped out a lot
cons: Some weeks are very easy others you are doing a lot of work. Having to do at least one closing a semester so make sure you plan accordingly

job_title: Bus Operator, Dispatcher in Amherst, MA
pros: Great work atmosphere, co-workers are awesome, supervisors are considerate of employee needs, there are employee appreciation days!!, flexible around schedules, pays for CDL B, promotes within, possibilities to advance in transportation field
cons: Must be a UMass student to begin career, bus service is free to general public so there are questionable characters on the bus frequently

pros: Love studying here and spend a great time living and doing research here, and also give nice opportunity to the job finding service.
cons: I don't really have any cons that I can think of everything is really great at this school and also pay more attention to the international students.

review_title: A very good place to do research
pros: Good for research work, the envrionement is generally quiet. You can focus on the work you are doing. The nearby towns are good for night life too.
cons: Bad location. This university may not be good for people just want to find a job. It's in a rural area where some companies would not come to do a campus career fair.

pros: Good & strong union. Great work/life balance. The job is what you make of it- some people loved it & some hated it- but, folks who worked hard & really focused on the positive really enjoy the position. I loved it.
cons: It is a big decentralized giant monster of a University.  Beyond that, there can be lots of bureaucratic 'stuff' to get through - which can be very challenging

pros: With Umass you can total control of the amount of time you can work. You'll have flexible hours, nice coworkers and bosses.
cons: You only earn minimum wage and can't earn a raise after a year of work. You also cannot exceed 20 hours of work a week.

pros: Lots of great co-workers, some people who really care, some who make the stereotype of the state worker true. Lots of time off Benefits.
cons: Overworked. Too many responsibilities put on a single person. High stress on a regular basis. Poor planning creates unneeded emergencies.

review_title: Great University that is under contract with Union
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Amherst, MA
pros: Pay was great and this position is unionized so that you cannot be fired without just cause. You also go through a meeting with union representation in that case. The position is manageable with school work and is funded through the department.
cons: The cons are entirely dependent on who you are assigned to work with. In my case, I had no cons.

review_title: An amazing manager and team to work with at the Instructional Media Lab.
pros: This review is specific to that particular job and environment. There is lots of training and support for the graduate assistants and a culture of respect, flexibility and collaboration.
cons: None for this job. If you are a graduate assistant you have excellent benefits that the union and student senate continue to fight for every year.

job_title: Dining Hall Worker in Amherst, MA
pros: Very easy job. You can not really mess anything up. The people there are fairly nice as well. Overall standard minimum wage job.
cons: It is a very boring job. Every day is essentially the same thing. The job can be fairly mind numbing.

pros: I love working in the lab. I learn so much from it. It is great for new graduates without experiences.
cons: I work from Monday to Sunday, but I do not have benefit. I only get paid by hours from Monday to Friday even though I work weekend too.

pros: I love becoming a part of the UMass community, learning how to have crucial conversations and confront social issues, gaining experience in leadership within a diverse community, becoming comfortable with being constantly on call.
cons: I had a very positive experience. My particular bosses are great, in that they advocate for me, trust me, encourage me, and express desire to help me with any and everything.

pros: The environment is great - my supervisor is very knowledgeable, my coworkers are engaged and I enjoy coming to work every day.
cons: The University is chronically understaffed and as a result you can be asked to do more than your fair share of work.  Hiring practices are also atrocious, and salaries aren't very competitive.

pros: You get paid for what you like to do. You get to lead your own research and meet a lot of people from different places. The atmosphere is very conducive to learning as is expected.
cons: Like any PhD the salary is not great. Can get stressful at times because you are the only one you can hang on to to get answers.

pros: Each day is a new learning. The colleagues are fantastic with varied backgrounds which adds to the learning. Complete freedom of work.
cons: Sometimes the freedom to work independently can be a problem. The work can be very slow at times.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Amherst, MA
pros: The job at UMass is really good. A lot of benefits are offered, including eye and dental and about 95% of health insurance is totally taken care of by the university making it excellent
cons: Depending on the research professor you work for, you can have a good time or a very difficult time doing and during your research period

pros: Great job to do at night which will not interfere with a class schedule. Very easy job, all you need to do is scan cards and check in guests. Great place to read a book, or do some written homework.
cons: It can be boring sometimes on quiet nights, and not laptops or cell phones are allowed to entertain oneself.

pros:
- you are paid for 10 hours a week regardless of whether the professor had you work the full 10 hours
- health and wellness benefits are amazing
- the graduate student workers union is strong
- beautiful area
- great academic environment
cons:
- low pay, not enough to sustain oneself independently 
- restaurants scene could be better
- rent is high

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Amherst, MA
pros:
Great Benefits
Graduate Employment Organization (GEO) is an old and active student union that makes sure you get great health insurance that include dental and vision
They also negotiate fo salary raises from time to time
cons: The minimum wage and number of hours per week varies across schools and departments, for example, Polymer Science  and Computer Science are significantly higher.

review_title: The university is a nice place  but the management is not willing to support the graduate employees
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Amherst, MA
pros: Nice people  generally, nice quite town, relatively  cheap , nice staff, nice students to work with, most advisors are nice
cons: Disrespectful management, no care for quality of lives of graduate students, limited resources available , some horrible advisors take advantage of poor management.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Amherst, MA
pros: Excellent and affordable health care thanks to the longstanding union: GEO
cons: The institution is very disorganized and the basic facts of billing, tuition waivers, and how your employment affects your student status will not be clear. Rely on your peers and the union for information as university employees in your department often do not have the correct information.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Amherst, MA
pros: The department has a very friendly culture.  Different Professors have different expectations so experiences can vary. My graduate career has been very positive.
cons: The core course need work and vary wildly in difficulty and in the quality of the teaching. Be prepared to self teach.

review_title: Geosciences department - fantastic environment for a graduate student
job_title: MS In Geosciences Candidate in Amherst, MA
pros: The geosciences department is very collegial.  Faculty are generally excited to provide support and guidance to any graduate student, and competition or politics never seem to hinder collaboration.
cons: There is not a particularly strong community among the graduate students.  However, the wider Amherst community is very welcoming and friendly.

pros:
-You choose your hours 
-Decent pay for college job 
-Boss is always cooperative and understanding 
-Environment is exciting and has lots to do
cons:
-Work is a bit much for the pay 
-Expectations are high 
-Too many students to manage at once

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Amherst, MA
pros: I enjoy the small-town setting, and the opportunity to spend time in the woods when the weather is nice.
cons: I had a hard time finding an adviser experienced in the career path I was interested in pursuing, thought to be fair, my interests are very different from most others in my field.

pros: Great hours, salary and benefits. An additional perk of the position is the fully funded graduate degree program. I would not have been able to pursue my education without the program and funding UMass provided me.
cons: There are very few downsides to being a graduate teaching assistant at UMass, in fact none immediately come to mind.

pros: Good students and friendly staff persons in the departments.
cons: New faculty are not supported by longer term faculty.   U Mass is a very hostile place to work.  Salary and job security for non-tenure track faculty are low.  Employees at U Mass are also not eligible for Social Security. The Massachusetts retirement program is very expensive not at all generous for young enrollees. The U Mass health insurance programs are all expensive, inadequate, and with high deductibles.

pros: The people are great and it's a great way to make some money while you're in school. I would do it again.
cons: There aren't many cons to be honest. If you don't have to work through college to make spending money, don't do it. But if you do, I would definitely work here.

pros: Tax School program is held within the Resource Economics Department at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.  Wonderful faculty and staff in Rescon Dept!  Position has autonomy; flexible schedule; project oriented work; and work independently ... all highly positive!!
cons: Some structures need work, but not truly a con since attention is given.

job_title: Market Research Analyst in Amherst, MA
pros:
collegiate atmosphere
friendly, open minded
very skilled people in a few departments
great location
work/life balance
tuition reimbursement (some)
fun place to work
cons:
salary is okay, could be higher given the cost of living
more career opportunities

review_title: Working as a student at Umass is the best thing you can do..
pros: Some great things include: having flexible hours (since you are a student first they understand that and work around your needs), the staff are all awesome, and working at umass pays pretty well!
cons: Not sure if there are any cons to be honest.

review_title: Operated Geotechnical Laboratory Testing of soil properties analysis for several projects
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Amherst, MA
pros: The position of graduate research assistant is a good position for a graduate student to learn and get more experience in this background.
cons: Lots of time need to be spent in the lab and many data analysis should be done in a tense time.

pros:
There are a lot of interesting people to meet
Many opportunities to collaborate and switch jobs across campus
Decent pay for a student
cons:
Highly disorganized, employees are hard to communicate with and organization is silo'd which makes creating meaningful organizational change a challenge.

Needed more guidance from my supervisor who I rarely saw

review_title: Big, complex organization but fulfilling work.
job_title: Director of Development in Amherst, MA
pros: Excellent faculty, students, interesting alumni. The work iself, raising resources for the academic mission, is very rewarding. Colleagues are a mix but many are professional and strive for excellence.
cons: Processes and performance metrics are used to manage a large group, but mean holistic review and quick sensible solutions aren't possible.

review_title: Good place to live, to work, but underpaid
job_title: Library Assistant II in Amherst, MA
pros: A good, relax, and safe neighborhood to live in. Working here feels good, all the co-workers are nice.
cons: Underpaid, considering the surrounding area being occupied by students, the housing rate is pretty high. No other allowance for an employee like a Meal supplement, no reward of any kind.

pros: Flexibile work schedule, self direction encouraged, excellent retirement and health care benefits
cons: Staff are treated as second class, regardless of professional success or research awards

pros: If you have to be in a small town - Amherst/Northampton is the place to be! Large international grad student community.
cons: Some of the facilities are outdated. Teaching is not the priority for this R1 institution

job_title: Customer Service Associate in Amherst, MA

cons: The office is open a lot, so you have some shifts at not great times- later at night, alternating weekends. You must make sure you remember the processes!!

review_title: High quality assistantship relative to most academic positions
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Amherst, MA
pros: The GEO ensures a bunch of benefits and fair pay which I've never in my previous experience or when searching for other graduate positions
cons: Departments can be clicky and there are clusters of researchers which can be dismissive of people outside of their field

job_title: Senior Research Fellow in Amherst, MA
pros: UMass Amherst really lives up to its fame. People are open-minded and were very welcoming. Even the salary was competitive with higher-ranked places such as MIT and Stanford
cons: Amherst is a really small town and UMass is the only game in town.

job_title: Student Support Consultant in Amherst, MA
pros: As far a student jobs on campus I would say this is probably one of the better ones. The job policies are fairly relaxed and the student managers have your back.
cons: Given how much information we are responsible for, minimum wage is a little low to start at.

review_title: Good Ph.D. and MS/Ph.D. Program, harder on the pure MS students
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant and Graduate Assistant in Amherst, MA
pros: The professors and peers in the program are brilliant and I very much enjoy working with them.
cons: The University doesn't treat people outside the CS department as well, and doesn't let Masters students work more than 4 hours a week.

job_title: Receiving Teller I in Amherst, MA
pros: Great pay, guaranteed step raise every year & cost of living increase.
cons: Lots of politics, if you don't know someone, you wont get any higher up the totem pole.

pros:
Great benefits as a grad student- especially with GEO

review_title: Great school, great people, great area
pros: Diverse student body, area full of hiking and biking, huge school resources, big research funding, overall a great choice

job_title: Student Staff At Franklin Dining Commons in Amherst, MA
pros: Regarding the dining commons, the hours are flexible to your schedule somewhat and it is easy to pick up extra shifts.
cons: Regarding the dining commons, stuff was stolen out of our lockers frequently and management did not care. They would often yell at staff for things outside their control.

job_title: UIA Teaching Assistant in Amherst, MA
pros: You typically get to work with a team of like-minded peers who are always willing help. Decent position with fair wages to help excel your career path while working towards your undergraduate degree. Manager(s) were always friendly

review_title: Great experience, sad it's no longer happening
pros: Working for SoccerFest was a great learning experience for myself and it allowed me to interact with so many of my collegiate peers.

pros: Good academic environment for research. All people there are very friendly. The campus is very beautiful.

pros: good package, comprehensive health care, free child care, people are considerate, nice gym, easy parking
